Want to talk to an expert about urban bike riding? Visit www.citibikenyc.com for information on free city cycling classes held frequently throughout NYC.
"Yield to pedestrians. Stay off the sidewalk. Obey traffic lights. Ride with traffic."
"You must be 16 or older to ride Citi Bike. Citi Bike encourages you to wear a helmet."
How It Works: About Citi Bike
An efficient way to get around NYC
Citi Bike is operated by NYC Bike Share LLC (a wholly-owned subsidiary of Alta Bicycle Share). It features thousands of bikes in hundreds of stations throughout NYC.
Citi Bike bicycles are durable, sturdy and regularly maintained. They can be rented using an Annual Member key or ride code that releases them from docking stations.

Citi Bike is designed for short trips around New York, so that bikes can be returned to stations within the allotted 30-minute window (45-minute for Annual Members) and become available for other riders. It is not intended for longer, all-day usage.
Find locations using a station map.
"Firmly push the bike into the dock and wait to see a green light blink on the dock to confirm it's been properly locked."
Select \"Request Time Credit\" on the start screen of the kiosk. You will have 15 minutes added to your trip time at no charge to find a nearby station with available docks.
Keep your eye on the clock.
Once your Pass has been purchased, rides up to 30 minutes (45 minutes with Annual Membership) are no extra charge. Extra charges apply for longer rides.
Ride as many times as you want during your Pass or Annual Membership period. Keep pedaling!

24-Hour and 7-Day Pass holders must request a new ride code to unlock another bike. Just swipe your credit or debit card at the kiosk to generate a new code. Your card will not be charged. Annual Members just dip their key into a dock to release another bike and ride again!
You must be 16 years old or older to ride a Citi Bike.

Purchase a 24-Hour or a 7-Day Pass. Passes are available for purchase by credit or debit card from any Citi Bike station. A $101 security hold will be placed on your card for every pass you purchase. Frequent rider? Join Citi Bike by signing up online for an Annual Membership!

24-Hour and 7-Day Pass holders are provided with a ride code. Type the code into the key pad on a dock with an available bike. Annual Members simply dip their own key into the key slot at any dock with an available bike.
Citi Bike seats are adjustable to fit a wide range of rider heights. Throw your bag into the front basket, strap it down and you’re ready to go!
Enter a word or phrase in the search bar to bring up exact matches as well as similarly-worded matches. Citi Bike stations will appear first in search results.
Simply tap on the station icon to get an exact number of bikes & docks available. For a quick estimate, the dark blue represents bikes and the light blue represents docks.

"There are two ways to get directions to a destination: 1) Search bar: Enter a search term and select a location from the generated list. 2) Map: Tap any station pin on the map to begin routing, or press and hold on any location on the map to prompt a location highlight."

Use the timer to keep track of your 30-minute time limit (45-minute for Annual Members). Please note that the timer will be just an estimate of your actual allotted time, since your 30 minutes begins the moment you unlock your bike.
Simply tap the “favorites” icon whenever you see it and the station or place will be automatically added to your own custom list. (This can be turned off in settings.)
As an option within map layers, you can opt to have all streets with bike lanes displayed in green.
Tap the layers icon and you’ll have various other options you can turn on & off that reveal such details as bike shops, Citi Branches and more.
"Each pin marks a station. Tap to get number of bikes and docks available."
Save all your favorite stations & places in one easy-to-access list.
Spring St a Elizabeth Street Stuff Goes Here
GPS is unavailable and not all features will work properly.
There was an error calculating the route. Please check your connection and try again.
There is only one station between you and your destination. Walking directions have been provided.
(Timer resets when you dock one bike and take another)
Overtime fees are charged for trips longer than 30 minutes. It’s an additional $4 for the second half hour, $9 for the third and $12 for every half hour after that.

That adds up quickly, so keep an eye on the clock and bring your bike back to any station when you get close to the end of your initial rental period. Find more details on overtime fees on citibikenyc.com/pricing.
Overtime fees are charged for trips longer than 45 minutes. It’s an additional $2.50 for the following half hour, $6.50 for the next and $9 for every half hour after that.
That adds up quickly, so keep an eye on the clock and bring your bike back to any station when you get close to the end of your initial rental period.
Please select a start and end address

The New York City Cycling Map is an annual free publication of DOT. Over 375,000 will be distributed this year from bicycle shops, libraries, and schools. You can also order your free copy by calling 311 (outside New York City, call 212-NEW-YORK).

The 2012 map has been completely redesigned. The city is no longer divided onto two halves, and a detailed inset gives a better view onto Manhattan, and adjoining parts of the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.

Bike Smart: The Official Guide to Cycling in New York City, provides information on how to make your ride safer and easier, including tips on using newer bike facilities such as protected lanes and bike boxes.
Need a helmet? Here are two ways to get your own:
Citi Bike encourages you to wear a helmet when you ride. Doing so can reduce the risk of head injury in the event of a crash while bicycling.
Always buckle the chin strap, and replace your helmet after any crash or whenever you see signs of damage.

Buy a helmet from a local bike shop or helmet retailer. Select the “Bike Shops” layer on the Citi Bike map to find the nearest retailer. Along with their Citi Bike key, every Annual Member receives a coupon good for $10 off one helmet at any bike shop in NYC.

Receive a free helmet and fitting from the Department of Transportation. NYC DOT fits and gives away the official New York City bicycle helmet at events throughout the city. Call 311 to schedule a fitting.
The more predictably you ride, the safer you are.
Don’t weave in and out of traffic
Use hand signals to let drivers and other cyclists know where you’re going
Ride about 4 feet away from parked cars, avoiding “the door zone”
Don’t ride distracted. It is illegal to ride with both headphones in.
Use your bell to alert drivers, pedestrians, and other cyclists of your presence

Use marked bike lanes or paths when available, except when marking turns or when it is unsafe to do so. If the road is too narrow for a bicycle and a car to travel safely side by side, you have the right to ride in the middle of the travel lane.
Bicycling is permitted on all main and local streets throughout New York City, even when no designated route exists.
NYC Bike Share maintains every bike to help ensure they are in good condition and working properly. It’s always a good idea to give the bike a look over before starting a ride.
If a bike isn’t working properly, lock it back into any Citi Bike dock, press the wrench button on the dock and unlock a different bike.
Check the following before you set off:

Citi Bike seats are easily adjustable. Just release the clamp on the side of the seat post, raise or lower the seat to your preferred height, align the black line in the center and re-tighten the clamp. Make sure the clamp is tight and the seat can’t twist or sink. Typically, a seat is at the right height when you can almost fully straighten your legs when pedaling.
Push each tire hard against a curb or the ground. If you can flatten it, it needs air.
Lift each wheel up and give it a slow spin (spin the back wheel forward so the pedals don’t move). Check that the wheel spins freely and doesn’t rub against the brake pads or anything else.
Turn each wheel slowly and look for cuts, bulges or bubbles in the tire.
Squeeze both brake levers to check that brakes are functional and feel strong.
If you are involved in a crash and anyone is injured, contact 911 immediately. File a police report at the nearest NYPD precinct and contact Citi Bike at 855-BIKE-311 (855-245-3311).
If your bike is not working properly, lock the bike into any available dock, press the wrench button on top of the dock, and take a new bike.
In the case of a lost or stolen Citi Bike key or bike, contact Citi Bike at 855-BIKE-311 (855-245-3311)
You must be at least 16 years old to ride Citi Bike.
Bicycles are defined as vehicles under New York State law. Cyclists have all the rights and are subject to all the duties and regulations applicable to drivers of motor vehicles.
For more information on NYC bicycle laws, check out NYCDOT’s BikeSmart guide or download a complete list of NYC bicycle laws, rules, and regulations.
Citi Bike encourages you to wear a helmet.
Ride responsibly, obey NYC traffic laws and wear a helmet.
Time’s Up! Return your Citi Bike before overtime fees kick-in.
The alarm can not be set for more than 10 hours from now.
